newsitem.title: FRANCE: French Communist to wear overalls to parliament.
newsitem.headline: French Communist to wear overalls to parliament.

text.p: A newly-elected French Communist deputy said he would wear blue overalls to the first session of parliament on Thursday to symbolise his working class roots.

"It's a symbol to show that...I am the only working class deputy starting this session, so I represent 70 percent of the French people who are in the same position as me as wage earners," Patrice Carvalho told France Info radio.

A mechanic who works at a French glassmakers, Carvalho said the National Assembly had many graduates from elite schools, civil servants or teachers, even though "they are not the essence of our nation."
Carvalho, 45, was one of 38 Communists elected to the 577-member Assembly in a Socialist-led victory last week. Male deputies usually wear dark suits in the Assembly.
The new Assembly was holding its first session at 3 p.m. (1300 GMT) on Thursday, with former Socialist prime minister Laurent Fabius set to be elected speaker.
Former Socialist culture minister Jack Lang caused a sensation in the 1980s by turning up to the Assembly dressed in a plain Chinese suit popularised by late chairman Mao Zedong.
